Programming Languages in Security Keynote Fred B. Schneider Samuel B. Eckert Professor of Computer 
Science Department of Computer Science Cornell University Ithaca, New York 14853 U. S. A. fbs@cs.cornell.edu 
Categories and Subject Descriptors D.4.6 [Security and Pro­tection]: Access controls, Information .ow 
controls, Veri.cation; F.3.1 [Specifying and Verifying and Reasoning about Programs]: Speci.cation techniques 
General Terms Security Keywords Science of Security Extended Abstract Are programming languages part 
of the problem or are they part of the solution for building secure systems? We explore this question, 
starting with the roles that programming languages currently do play in building secure systems and roles 
that they could play. But to focus on language details misses some key opportunities. Progress in programming 
languages is an exemplar for a disci­pline s transition from an art to a craft to a science that informs 
en­gineering. Moreover, evidence mounts that the same science base developed within the programming languages 
community is also useful for building a science of security. We will explore the simi­larities and discuss 
how a science of security is likely to be differ­ent. We characterize properties that one might expect 
for a science of security, and we discuss the utility and limitations of existing language-based techniques 
in supporting that agenda. To illustrate, we explore some foundational problems in cyber-security: What 
does security mean for a system? This is clearly a speci.­cation question, but it has different scope 
than speci.cations for ordinary programs. Fundamental models studied in the formal methods community 
need to be revisited.  How can we characterize classes of defense mechanisms and impose useful structure 
on that space? Is it in terms of attacks that will be resisted, policies that will be enforced, or orthogo­nality 
and limits to compositionality?  How do we reconcile the two primary metaphors for authoriza­tion: access 
control versus information-.ow control. Are they linked by notions of universality or by interesting 
reduction re­lations?  Acknowledgments Schneider is supported in part by AFOSR grants F9550-06-0019 
and FA9550-11-1-0137, National Science Foundation grants 0430161, 0964409, and CCF-0424422 (TRUST), ONR 
grants N00014-01-1-0968 and N00014-09-1-0652, and grants from Microsoft. Copyright is held by the author/owner(s).
